TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine-loamy, mixed, superactive, mesic Xeric Argidurids

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Arbidge sandy loam -- on a slope of 2 percent under native vegetation at 1,525 meters elevation.  When described on April 24, 1978, the soil profile was moist to 38 cm and dry below.  (Colors are for air dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
A--0 to 10 cm; brown (10YR 5/3) sandy loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; weak fine granular structure; soft, very friable; many very fine to coarse roots; many very fine irregular pores; neutral (pH 7.2); abrupt smooth boundary.  (5 to 15 cm thick)
Bt1--10 to 20 cm; yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) sandy clay loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; many very fine and fine roots; many very fine and fine tubular pores; very few faint clay films on faces of peds and in pores; slightly alkaline (pH 7.4); gradual wavy boundary.  (5 to 18 cm thick)
Bt2--20 to 38 cm; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) sandy clay loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure; hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common very fine and fine roots; many very fine and fine tubular pores; few faint clay films on faces of peds and in pores; slightly alkaline (pH 7.6); clear smooth boundary.  (15 to 38 cm thick)
Bk--38 to 66 cm; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) sandy loam, brown (10YR 5/3) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure; very hard, firm, nonsticky and nonplastic; few very fine and fine roots; few fine tubular pores; 5 percent durinodes 1.2 to 2.5 cm in diameter; strongly effervescent (13 percent calcium carbonate), few fine carbonate filaments; moderately alkaline (pH 8.4); clear smooth boundary.  (25 to 36 cm thick)
Bkqm--66 to 69; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) duripan, brown (10YR 5/3) moist; massive; extremely hard, extremely firm; thin (1.5 to 3.0 mm thick) continuous laminar opal cap; fractures are 0.6 cm wide and 20 cm apart; few very fine and fine roots through fractures; strongly effervescent; clear smooth boundary.  (0 to 15 cm thick)
2Bk--69 to 94 cm; very pale brown (10YR 7/4) sandy loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; massive; slightly hard, friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; common very fine to coarse roots; common very fine tubular pores; 10 percent durinodes 1.2 to 2.5 cm in diameter; 10 percent gravel; strongly effervescent (11 percent calcium carbonate); moderately alkaline (pH 8.4); abrupt wavy boundary.  (0 to 12 inches thick)
2Bkqm--94 to 102 cm; very pale brown (10YR 8/3) duripan, very pale brown (10YR 7/3) moist; massive; extremely hard, extremely firm; thin ( 1.5 toto 3 mm thick) continuous laminar opal cap; fractures are less than 0.3 cm wide and more than 25 cm apart; few very fine roots through fractures; strongly effervescent; clear wavy boundary.  (5 to 20 cm thick)
3C--102 to 165 cm; multi-colored extremely gravelly sand; single grain; few very fine roots; carbonate and silica coatings on undersides of gravel.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Twin Falls County, Idaho; about 5 miles southwest of Rogerson, Idaho, in the northwest 1/4, northwest 1/4, southwest 1/4, sec. 26, T. 14 S., R. 15 E.; USGS Salmon Butte 7.5 minute topographic quadrangle; latitude 42 degrees 10 minutes 44 seconds N and longitude 114 degrees 20 minutes 22 seconds W; WGS84 Decimal Degrees 42.1788889 latitude, -114.6727778 longitude.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:
Depth to duripan - 20 to 40 inches.
Depth to sand and gravel - 22 to more than 40 inches.
Average annual soil temperature - 47 to 53 degrees F.
Depth to calcium carbonate - 10 to 25 inches.
A horizon
Value - 4 through 6 dry, 2 through 4 moist.
Chroma - 2 or 3 dry or moist.
Bt horizon
Value - 4 through 6 dry, 2 through 4 moist.
Chroma - 2 through 4 dry or moist.
Texture - L, CL, SCL.
Clay content - 20 to 34 percent.
Coarse fragments - 0 to 10 percent gravel.
Bk horizon
Value - 6 through 8 dry, 4 through 6 moist.
Chroma - 2 through 4 dry or moist.
Texture - FSL, SL, SCL, GR-SL, GR-SCL.
Coarse fragments - 0 to 20 percent gravel.
Reaction - mildly or moderately alkaline.
Calcium carbonate equivalent - 5 to 15 percent.
Bkqm horizon
Laminar capping - indurated continuous to nearly continuous.  Structure - massive or platy.
Distance between fractures - 4 to 15 inches.
Width of fractures - 1/4 inch or less.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Dacker, Deerlodge, Ditchcamp, Exel, Idow, Lembos, Madras, Ochoco, Rakane, Snowmore, Wako, Wellsed, and Wendell series.  Dacker soils have SIL or SICL Bt horizons.  Deerlodge soils have 7.5YR hue in the B2t horizons and have up to 35 percent gravel in the argillic horizon. Ditchcamp soils are slightly acid or neutral throughout and are noncalcareous throughout the profile.  Exel soils have 5YR or 7.5YR hues in the argillic horizons and lack carbonates in the profile.  Idow, Rakane and Wako soils have duripans more than 10 inches thick.  Lembos soils are calcareous throughout.  Madras, Snowmore and Wendell soils are less than 40 inches deep to bedrock.  Ochoco soils have 20 percent or more pumice in the solum.  Wellsed soils have 15 to 35 percent coarse fragments in the Bt and are moist for 10 to 20 day cumulative between July and October.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Arbidge soils are on stream and lacustrine terraces, fan terraces, plug domes, calderas, tablelands, and alluvial plains.  The slope range is 1 to 15 percent.  The soils formed in old alluvium and loess from extrusive rocks and volcanic ash.  Elevations are 3,000 to 5,500 feet.  The average annual precipitation ranges from 9 to 13 inches.  The average annual temperature is 45 to 51 degrees F. The frost-free period is 85 to 130 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Chuska, Lankbush, Owsel, and Udaho soils.  Lankbush soils occur just above the Arbidge soils on the landscape and lack a duripan.  Chuska soils are on terraces, dipslopes, and ridges and are shallow to a duripan.  Owsel soils are on terraces and basins and lack a duripan.  Udaho soils are on sideslopes and backslopes, are skeletal and moderately deep to welded ash.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained, slow or medium runoff; moderately slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Arbidge soils are used for rangeland, wildlife habitat, and irrigated cropland.  Wheat, potatoes, barley, and alfalfa hay are the principal irrigated crops.  The potential natural plant community is mainly bluebunch wheatgrass, Thurber needlegrass, needleandthread, Wyoming big sagebrush, and antelope bitterbrush.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Arbidge soils are of moderate extent in south central and southwestern Idaho.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Davis, California

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Owyhee County, Idaho; Duck Valley Indian Reservation Idaho-Nevada, 1984.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon are:
Ochric epipedon - the zone from 0 to 10 cm (A horizon).
Argillic horizon - the zone from 10 to 38 cm (Bt horizons).
Duripans - the zones from 66 to 69 cm and from 94 to 102 cm (Bkqm and 2Bkqm horizons).
Particle-size control section - the zone from 10 to 38 (Bt1 and Bt2 Horizons).
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
